adjective.description: Causing difficulty; hard to do or deal with.
examples: the wheelbarrow can be awkward to maneuver
one of the most awkward jobs is painting a ceiling

adjective.description: Causing or feeling embarrassment or inconvenience.
examples: he had put her in a very awkward situation
Luther's awkward movements impeded his progress
she was long-legged and rather awkward

origin: Late Middle English (in the sense the wrong way round, upside down): from dialect awk backwards, perverse, clumsy (from Old Norse afugr turned the wrong way) + -ward.
